awd_titl_txt: GP-EXTRA: GEOTeams: Summer Research Pathways to Geoscience Using a Novel Multilevel Team Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1 - As students are prepared for global change, there's an obligation to educate them in the significance of human impacts on Earth systems through the study of geoscience. The growing geoscience job market will present exciting new opportunities to contribute to the sustainability and well being of society; however, for a variety of reasons, students are not being made aware of these opportunities. The problem is particularly acute among underrepresented minority (URM, or Black, Hispanic, American Indian/Alaskan Native) students. This program applies a novel multi-level approach of engaging students at different stages in their education in a five week summer research project related to the challenges of living sustainably on Long Island. Four teams each year made up of an undergraduate science major, a high school student, and a future science teacher will perform hands on research closely mentored by expert faculty. The ultimate goal is to increase the number of students (particularly those underrepresented in the STEM pipeline) pursuing geoscience related degrees and planning on entering geoscience professions. In addition, the program seeks to strengthen the ability of future teachers to inspire students and influence their future STEM learning and interest in STEM careers, and to raise awareness among teachers of the research opportunities in the geosciences. 

Part 2 - During an intensive 5 week program, GEOTeam members will engage in collaborative, authentic, scientific inquiry on projects that focus on hydrogeology, sedimentology, geohazards, climate, and biogeochemistry. Weekly seminars and workshops will introduce students to research processes, safety training, and career development through interaction with geoscience professionals from local governments and businesses. GEOTeams will present their work and results in professional settings such as science fairs, conferences, and public meetings. The project capitalizes on several outstanding Hofstra programs, including the Summer Science Research Program; a STEM Collaboratorium; established connections with area public schools, particularly high need schools; the STEP and CSTEP collegiate preparatory programs for underrepresented students; and the Noyce Scholars Program. The project provides new insights on engaging students raised in a developed environment with limited exposure to geology a significant topic which has not yet received adequate attention. It adds to the knowledge base on how the strategic use of team?\based learning rooted in a collaborative process can impact the performance of students, particularly underrepresented students, in geoscience. It enhances the infrastructure for science teacher education by improving science teachers' ability to advance student learning through authentic research. 

The project explores how universities can directly engage high school students in explorations of geoscience early in their studies before they lose interest. Finally, project findings should contribute to [best practices] in STEM instruction for underserved minority students and increase their self\efficacy and performance in mathematics and science, thus expanding their opportunities for STEM careers. The students' engagement in authentic, career\relevant geoscience experiences will give them a concrete understanding of key knowledge and skills in the field and the importance of geoscience in solving real world problems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

por.por_cntn:
A projected shortage of geoscience professionals in the United States, and the lack of diversity among them, motivated the creation of the GEOTeams program at Hofstra University (HU). Four teams pursued authentic geoscience research projects for six weeks each summer between 2021 and 2023, each team working with one professor in the HU Geology, Environment, and Sustainability (GES) Department. Studies have found that engaging students in such activities enhances the educational experience of the students and attracts more of them to pursue careers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). The main innovation of this summer geoscience research program was the formation of teams comprised of participants from multiple levels of education and career preparation, including teachers. Each "GEOTeam" consisted of a high school student, an undergraduate STEM major, and a pre-service or in-service teacher. The purpose of this model of geoscience education is to allow students from various educational levels to mentor and encourage each other in the process of doing science, while preparing teachers to incorporate geoscience research into their classrooms.

Goals of the program included: 1) engaging GEOTeams members in collaborative, authentic, scientific inquiry doing geoscience; 2) deepening interest in and knowledge of geoscience thinking; 3) introducing team members to geoscience career possibilities; 4) including multiple members of underrepresented groups (blacks or African Americans, Hispanics or Latinos, and American Indians or Alaska Natives. as defined by the National Center for Science and Engineering Statistics) each year; and 5) strengthening the ability of pre-service teachers to inspire their students in the study of geoscience.

Several activities were arranged to accomplish these goals. Workshops on lab and field safety, searching the scientific literature, scientific methods, mapping, and scientific writing helped program participants gain skills in geoscience research. Research projects included finding the age of a Long Island glacial erratic, estimating sea surface temperatures over the past approximately 160,000 years using microfossil abundance, measuring heat output of volcanoes in Greece, and analyzing air quality in New York City and on Long Island. All research projects culminated in participants presenting their results at a poster session of the HU Summer Science Research Program. In addition to pursuing intensive research projects, program participants attended seminars presented by representatives from government environmental agencies, non-profit environmental organizations, and environmental consulting firms, who gave overviews of their careers and insights into their work experiences.

The GEOTeams program met its goals, according to external evaluation. All respondents to a final survey of participants in the GEOTeams program (N=11) indicated that they were "somewhat satisfied" (N=1) or "satisfied" (N=10) with their participation in the program. All (N=11) said they had learned about geoscience. Most (N=9) said they had gained research skills that they could use in their career, and most (N=9) said they could list their experiences on a job/school application. When asked about the benefits of working in cohort teams, all (N=11) appreciated hearing different perspectives, and most (N=10) cited learning from students with different experiences. Most (N=9) appreciated making connections with people they would otherwise never have met. When asked about any "fun" aspect of the program in a free-response text box, one student cited "I really enjoyed getting to work as a team." 

For more information about the GEOTeams program, please watch for this forthcoming publication:

Farmer, E.C., Hecht, D., Bennington, JB. Marsellos, A.M. and Bernhardt, J.E. (in press). "GEOTeams: An innovative multilevel team approach in summer research pathways to geoscience." GEOPATHS--Broadening the Voices in Geosciences: Pathways to Innovative Pedagogy and Professional Development. Jamie MacDonald, Renee Clary, Ruby Broadway, Reginald Archer, Eds. Geological Society of America.
